description:
Course content is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family unit. 

Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional Technology Center (ITC). The student will care for families with both simple and complex needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student will assist in managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and neonatal periods.
name: NURSING OF THE CHILDBEARING FAMILY: THEORY/CLINICAL

section.name: NURSING OF THE CHILDBEARING FAMILY: THEORY/CLINICAL

values.comments:
This course is a theory and clinical based course that is a requirement for all students in the School of Nursing. Course content is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family unit. Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional Technology Center (ITC). The student will care for families with both simple and complex needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student will assist in managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and neonatal periods.

Many students found this course enjoyable, informative, and interesting. One student referred to the course as, “a very exciting experience,” and another claims it to be, “my favorite class in the major so far.” Students report that this course is very comprehensive in covering all topics of maternity and the childbearing family despite its short 7 week time frame. Students found article readings to be useful and enjoyed discussing relevant “current OB practice.” “I left this course with solid exposure to pre-natal through post-natal experience and care,” one student remarked. A number of guest lecturers were brought in to teach more specifically on several topics. Many students were impressed with the lecturers and found them knowledgeable; however a few students found that this created inconsistency and a “jumbled, non-sequential feel”.

Professor Stern does a great job inviting relevant guest lecturers that are very knowledgeable and comprehensive on their specific topics. Very few students made specific comments about Professor Stern because she takes more of a behind the scenes role in this course.

Course content for this course was divided into two major exams which students felt were long and “difficult.” Students were also given a chance for an “alternate community clinical experience.” This experience seemed to be valuable for most students, however some found it difficult to arrange. A major assignment that is a part of this course is a cultural/ethical research paper. For the most part, the experience of researching and writing this paper was “enjoyable.” A number of students critiqued this assignment, saying that it had a rigid and limiting structure that was not conducive to learning. Although this course is mostly made up of juniors in nursing, one student states that it would be “very interesting even to non-majors.” The pre-requisites for this class include N104, N106, N131 and N132.

section.name: NURSING OF THE CHILDBEARING FAMILY: THEORY/CLINICAL

values.comments:
This course is a theory and clinical based course that is a requirement for all students in the School of Nursing. Course content is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family unit. Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional Technology Center (ITC). The student will care for families with both simple and complex needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student will assist in managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and neonatal periods.

Many students found this course enjoyable, informative, and interesting. One student referred to the course as, “a very exciting experience,” and another claimed it to be, “my favorite class in the major so far.” Students report that this course is very comprehensive in covering all topics of maternity and the childbearing family despite its short 7 week time frame. Students found article readings to be useful and enjoyed discussing relevant “current OB practice.” “I left this course with solid exposure to pre-natal through post-natal experience and care,” one student remarked. A number of guest lecturers were brought in to teach more specifically on several topics. Many students were impressed with the lecturers and found them knowledgeable; however a few students found that this created inconsistency and a “jumbled, non-sequential feel.”

Professor Guidera, a practicing midwife, seemed to be very well-liked by her students and was cited for her “passion about the subject” and “valuable insight.” One student states that Professor Guidera is, “clearly an excellent provider who respects pregnancy and birth and does a good job conveying her knowledge.” Other words used to describe Professor Guidera include “stimulating,” “inspiring,” and “approachable.” One of the only complaints about Professor Guidera is that she is difficult to contact and often does not answer e-mails promptly if at all.

Course content for this course was divided into two major exams which students felt were long and “difficult.” Students were also given a chance for an “alternate community clinical experience.” This experience seemed to be valuable for most students, however some found it difficult to arrange. A major assignment that is a part of this course is a cultural/ethical research paper. For the most part, the experience of researching and writing this paper was “enjoyable.” A number of students critiqued this assignment, saying that it had a rigid and limiting structure that was not conducive to learning. Although this course is mostly made up of juniors in nursing, one student states that it would be “very interesting even to non-majors.” The pre-requisites for this class include N104, N106, N131, and N132.

Professor Stern does a great job inviting relevant guest lecturers that are very knowledgeable and comprehensive on their specific topics. Very few students made specific comments about Professor Stern because she takes more of a behind the scenes role in this course.

A major assignment that is a part of this course is a cultural/ethical research paper. For the most part, the experience of researching and writing this paper was “enjoyable.” A number of students critiqued this assignment, saying that it had a rigid and limiting structure that was not conducive to learning. Although this course is mostly made up of juniors in nursing, one student states that it would be “very interesting even to non-majors.” The pre-requisites for this class include N104, N106, N131 and N132.

Course content is based on a family centered approach in which the needs of the family members during various phases of the childbearing process are considered. The student is provided with a theory base necessary for the care of women, families, and their newborns. This theory base is organized according to the concepts of the person or family, environment, health and nursing and their relation to each other during childbearing. Using the nursing process, nursing strategies are developed for maintaining family members individually, for promoting optimal physiological and psychological functioning, and enhancing strengths within the family members and within the family unit. Clinical experiences provide opportunities for application and integration of the theory base with parents and newborns. The student participates in clinical experiences in a variety of settings including acute care facilities, the community, and the Instructional Technology Center (ITC). The student will care for families with both simple and complex needs in all phases of the childbearing cycle. During this course, the student will assist in managing the care of families during the antepartum, intrapartum, postpartum, and neonatal periods.

Students, overall, felt the skills lab portion of this class was “disorganized” but taught them important theory and skills. Many commented that the textbook was not very helpful in answering the questions for the modules. However, these students did say that the text was a good resource overall for nursing procedures. There was a good amount of discontent regarding the variability and inconsistencies among the lab instructors. As a result, most students were concerned that the exams did not take into account the different information received from various teachers. In general, though, the students agree that the “skills learned… are very helpful.”

Professor Iorianni-Cimbak was described as “extremely knowledgeable and helpful” and “great about finding time to meet and explain concepts to people.” Students found Professor Iorianni-Cimbak accessible via email and occasionally in person. Each lab section had a different instructor so many of the comments related to these individuals rather than to Professor Iorianni-Cimbak specifically.

Students were dissatisfied with the large amounts of work required for this course since it was only worth a low percentage of the overall class grade. The modules were described as “busy work” by many of the students. Others did not appreciate the “unnecessarily long” exams after the equally long validation sessions. Yet, one student stated that the lab “is very valuable in preparing us to be good nurses.” This portion of the course is open to junior nursing students only. Students from other majors should not take this course. The prerequisites include N104, N106, N131 and N132.

values.name: NURSING OF THE CHILDBEARING FAMILY: THEORY/CLINICAL
